content.body: isn't that expected?
returning skips the rest of the callback, but not subsequent iterations, because they're different runs of the callback
the issue only comes when porting code that uses a for loop to code using `forEach`
content.formatted_body: the issue only comes when porting code that uses a for loop to code using forEach

content.body: I suspect what they're asking for is for the article to point out you cannot break out of the loop.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I suspect what they're asking for is for the article to point out you cannot break out of the loop.

content.body:
There is already a section for this that says: "There is no way to stop or break a forEach() loop other than by throwing an exception"
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach#sect2
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text:
There is already a section for this that says: "There is no way to stop or break a forEach() loop other than by throwing an exception"
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach#sect2

content.body: maybe it could be even more explicit?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: maybe it could be even more explicit?

content.body: Good point, dunno then.

OK, thanks all — yeah, seems like the OP just had the expectation that the `return` would break out of the `forEach()`. So I guess I’ll add something to the _“There is no way to stop or break a `forEach()` loop other than by throwing an exception”_ note explicitly saying that a `return` will not break out of the `forEach()` but will instead just return from the current call to the callback function, and the continue the loop.
content.formatted_body: OK, thanks all — yeah, seems like the OP just had the expectation that the return would break out of the forEach(). So I guess I’ll add something to the “There is no way to stop or break a forEach() loop other than by throwing an exception” note explicitly saying that a return will not break out of the forEach() but will instead just return from the current call to the callback function, and the continue the loop.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: OK, thanks all — yeah, seems like the OP just had the expectation that the `return` would break out of the `forEach()`. So I guess I’ll add something to the _“There is no way to stop or break a `forEach()` loop other than by throwing an exception”_ note explicitly saying that a `return` will not break out of the `forEach()` but will instead just return from the current call to the callback function, and the continue the loop.

OK, thanks all — yeah, seems like the OP just had the expectation that the return would break out of the forEach(). So I guess I’ll add something to the “There is no way to stop or break a forEach() loop other than by throwing an exception” note explicitly saying that a return will not break out of the forEach() but will instead just return from the current call to the callback function, and the continue the loop.

content.body: Check for my own sanity: The fact that https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence puts `? :` on a precedence level tighter than `=` and `yield` is incorrect, right?

content.body: it's not really meaningful to talk about precedence for a ternary as a whole
but `yield a ? b : c` is `yield (a ? b : c)` and `x = a ? b : c` is `x = (a ? b : c)`
content.formatted_body: but yield a ? b : c is yield (a ? b : c) and x = a ? b : c is x = (a ? b : c)

content.body: * but `yield a ? b : c` is `yield (a ? b : c)` and `x = a ? b : c` is `x = (a ? b : c)`
content.formatted_body: * but yield a ? b : c is yield (a ? b : c) and x = a ? b : c is x = (a ? b : c)

m.new_content.body: but `yield a ? b : c` is `yield (a ? b : c)` and `x = a ? b : c` is `x = (a ? b : c)`

content.body: so to the extent there is precedence at all, I think it's correct to say that `yield` binds less tightly than `? :`
content.formatted_body: so to the extent there is precedence at all, I think it's correct to say that yield binds less tightly than ? :

content.body: Point taken. This is mostly a result of the weird interactions between ternary and unary/binary operators…
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Point taken. This is mostly a result of the weird interactions between ternary and unary/binary operators…

content.body: well, and assignment
`yield` is less weird because `yield a` is always `yield a` in any of the three positions
content.formatted_body: yield is less weird because yield a is always yield a in any of the three positions

content.body: but assignment is weird because `a = b ? c : d` parses as assignment-containing-ternary whereas `a ? b : c = d` parses as ternary-containing-assignment
content.formatted_body: but assignment is weird because a = b ? c : d parses as assignment-containing-ternary whereas a ? b : c = d parses as ternary-containing-assignment

content.body: Yeah, and assignment’s weird asymmetry too.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah, and assignment’s weird asymmetry too.

content.body: `=` and `=>` are both more like…prefix unary operators on their RHS. (With possible evaluation on any default expressions in their LHS afterwards.)
content.formatted_body: = and => are both more like…prefix unary operators on their RHS. (With possible evaluation on any default expressions in their LHS afterwards.)

= and => are both more like…prefix unary operators on their RHS. (With possible evaluation on any default expressions in their LHS afterwards.)

content.body: (All of this weirdness is also why we are banning mixing any of these within `|>` pipe expressions without parentheses.)

content.body: Still think that forEach should be extended to pass the callback a fourth argument that's a "halt token", which stops execution if you return it. Then the four callback arguments will be Element, Index, Collection, Halt, or EICH
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Still think that forEach should be extended to pass the callback a fourth argument that's a "halt token", which stops execution if you return it. Then the four callback arguments will be Element, Index, Collection, Halt, or EICH

content.body: Or just don't use forEach... for-of is just way better IMO.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Or just don't use forEach... for-of is just way better IMO.

content.body: https://ericlippert.com/2009/05/18/foreach-vs-foreach/
Yeah, but Tab has a point: we would get an EICH abbreviation in the language. The next step would be to somehow add BRENDAN somewhere.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah, but Tab has a point: we would get an EICH abbreviation in the language. The next step would be to somehow add BRENDAN somewhere.

content.body: right, that's the whole point. not worth doing it otherwise

content.body: Given that `1 ? x = 2 : 3` groups as `1 ? (x = 2) : 3` and that `1 ? x => 2 : 3` groups as `1 ? (x => 2) : 3`, is it fair to say that `? :` is acting “looser” than `=` or `=>` here?
content.formatted_body: Given that 1 ? x = 2 : 3 groups as 1 ? (x = 2) : 3 and that 1 ? x => 2 : 3 groups as 1 ? (x => 2) : 3, is it fair to say that ? : is acting “looser” than = or => here?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Given that `1 ? x = 2 : 3` groups as `1 ? (x = 2) : 3` and that `1 ? x => 2 : 3` groups as `1 ? (x => 2) : 3`, is it fair to say that `? :` is acting “looser” than `=` or `=>` here?
Given that 1 ? x = 2 : 3 groups as 1 ? (x = 2) : 3 and that 1 ? x => 2 : 3 groups as 1 ? (x => 2) : 3, is it fair to say that ? : is acting “looser” than = or => here?

content.body: I wouldn't describe it that way personally, since that it is also true that `a => b ? c : d` groups as `a => (b ? c : d)`
content.formatted_body: I wouldn't describe it that way personally, since that it is also true that a => b ? c : d groups as a => (b ? c : d)

content.body: you can't really say one is strictly looser than the other

Yeah. The whole concept of “precedence” breaks down at this level…I’m not sure how to explain where `|>` (which has similar “precedence” as these) fits in with them in laypersons’ terms (let alone explaining how `yield`, `=`, `=>`, and `? :` interact in such terms).
content.formatted_body: Yeah. The whole concept of “precedence” breaks down at this level…I’m not sure how to explain where |> (which has similar “precedence” as these) fits in with them in laypersons’ terms (let alone explaining how yield, =, =>, and ? : interact in such terms).

content.body: I don't think laypeople think in terms of precedence
just give examples of how various things would be grouped like we've been doing here
it's by far the clearest way to explain
